0765350386|5.0|Mistborn is part Epic Fantasy and part Superhero Origin Story. Taking place in a unique world, Mistborn delivers action, adventure, and drama.     Plot:   An omnipotent lord rules the land with brutality and terror. Armed soldiers take joy in beating a helpless population into submission. Magic wielding Inquisitors strike fear into their hearts through torture and death. Wealthy aristocratic houses attempt to outmaneuver each other politically and economically. The Skaa, a once proud race, have been conquered, enslaved, and worked to death in slums, plantations, and mines. But hope lies in the mists as rebels plan a revolution.     World:   Brandon Sanderson does an excellent job creating and building an exciting new Fantasy World complete with its own magic system based on consuming metals. In the day, ash falls from blood red skies. At night, the land is engulfed in darkness and mist. Mistwraiths haunt the lands at night, and the Inquisitors roam the city streets in the day. Those who are Mistborne use a magic system called Allomancy and consuming types of metal gives them powers. Pewter enhances physical abilities, Tin enhances perception, Steel pushes metals with tremendous force... Imagine a coin going right through someone's head. This book is worth reading based on the unique universe and magic system alone. The book also features a useful glossary at the end that explains the types of mages and magic.     Characters:   The main character is a street urchin named Vin. She's likeable, clever, and tough. For the most part, the characters are well written. There are some that could use more screen time and the dialogue could have been a bit better at times. But overall, they're good.     Action:   This book contains some very unique action scenes that may be described as a cross between The Matrix and The X-Men set in a fantasy universe. There are some fairly long breaks in the action, but when there is action, it's great.     Balls:   This book has Balls; the expensive, fancy dress, snooty, dancing kind. This is where the political aristocratic house warfare takes place. These chapters could be annoying for angsty fantasy fans that want pure action. These scenes slow the pacing of the book just a bit. But if you're mature enough to enjoy a glass of wine, you'll like these scenes. To the angsty action fans (like me), they're not so bad and trust me; you'll really want to get to the end of this book!     Overall:   This is a refreshingly original fantasy adventure with action, subterfuge, and magic. I'd give it a 4.5 outta 5!     If you like fantasy books that have world building, originality, action, and BALLS pick this one up! You'll enjoy it!     If you want traditional fantasy with elves, dragons, castles, knights on a quest, or you aren't a fan of balls, then you can avoid this one.   (But you'd still probably enjoy it, if you gave it a shot.)
B000WC39ZY|3.0|Oh my.  Where do I begin?  If I had been Martin Scorsese's assistant during pre-production of \\"New York, New York\\", I might have said something like \\"Marty, you know I love your movies.  I suspect you walk on water in your spare time, and can film just about any film genre known to humanity, but you gotta pass on this screenplay, because you can't make a silk purse from a sow's ear.\\"     There's a lot to like and a lot not to like in \\"New York, New York\\", but the unlikeable parts boil down to: bad screenplay.      The basic premise of the film is simple.  Jimmy (Robert DeNiro), a saxophone player just out of the military in 1945 meets and falls in love with Francine (Liza Minnelli), a small-time singer with a touring big band.  Francine becomes much more famous than Jimmy, things don't work out between Francine and Jimmy.  So far, so good. More about what's good and what's bad about the movie.    What's good:  The music is great.  Big band and jazz from the 1940s, excellent musicianship.  The singing by Liza Minnelli is also superb.  A musical medley taking up the last half-hour of the film is also sensational.  Set design is perfect for re-creating the mood of some of the lavish musicals from the 1940s and 1950s.     What's bad:  The biggest problem with the film is that Jimmy's character is completely unlikeable.  He spends the first part of the film at a VJ day (WW II end of war victory) celebration party where he's asking women for a date.  Jimmy focuses on Francine and unrelentingly bothers her for a full fifteen minutes of screen time asking her out, trying out every line he can think of.  Essentially, Jimmy comes across as a crazed stalker who will not take no for an answer.  DeNiro's performance is really creepy, but I'm not sure if he intended it to be.  He appears to be channeling the Travis Bickle character from Taxi Driver.  The Bickle character is believable because we know he's a psychopath, but we also know he wants to \\"clean up the city\\" from all thebad elements.  The Jimmy character comes across as just a manipulative, self-centered egomaniac who only thinks of himself.      Eventually, Jimmy and Francine marry, but that doesn't mean Jimmy becomes a better person.  A few thoughts came to my mind when I watched their relationship develop:  Jimmy is a chauvinist pig, arrogant, controlling, and despicable.  Francine allows herself to be treated like a doormat by Jimmy.  She's emotionally abused constantly, yet maintains a strange acceptance of her mistreatment, wearing a bemused, detached expression like she's the Buddha who has been reincarnated as a dancing girl.  I wanted to warn Francine, \\"Stand up for yourself, you don't have to take this from him.  Read \\"Women Who Love Too Much\\", can't you see that you have a toxic relationship with this man?\\" (Oh, where's Oprah or Dr. Phil when you need them?)    DeNiro's performance in New York, New York is similar to his previous film with Scorsese, Taxi Driver.  What works for a mentally unstable loner in Taxi Driver simply does not translate to a married saxophone player in a respected band.  I for one, did not accept that the Jimmy character should have been given a single second of respect.  Minnelli's performance, as previously noted, is a little strange; extremely calm and quiet, and almost under-acted.  It's like she was afraid to let the Francine character ever let her emotions show.  I suspect she was told to play the part like a woman with battered wife syndrome - very shut down emotionally.      I believe that the main reason this film did not do well is because American audiences were not willing to embrace the two main characters of the film; the man is emotionally abusive, and the woman is meekly accepting of her abuse.  The story isn't even really a tragedy, it's a pathetic reminder that some people should never meet and fall in love.  I suspect also that American audiences craved a stronger female lead who wouldn't take any guff from anybody - hence thegreat success of two films with very strong female characters made shortly after New York, New York; namely, Karen Allen in Raiders of the Lost Ark, and Sigourney Weaver in Alien.      Although Scorsese went on to make the brilliant Raging Bull, again with DeNiro as an abusive man, at least in that film, his character's relationship with his wife Vicky is easier to accept because Vicky is one tough broad who can stand up for herself, who gives as good as she gets, dishing it right back out.  The Minnelli character is just a sad, pathetic character.  One of Scorsese's weakest efforts, recommend you skip this film.
1594202249|5.0|I always used to think of \\"The Crying of Lot 49\\" as the obvious entry point to the work of my favorite author. It may have had some dense prose, but at least it was short.<br />A new portal has been opened.<br />\\"Inherent Vice\\" is both short and easy to read, but it's still recognizably the work of Thomas Pynchon even if the pink flaps of the dustjacket are visually jarring as you read the remarkably unconvoluted sentences and short paragraphs. Despite the surprisingly atypical cover (\\"Mason & Dixon\\" and \\"Against the Day\\" appear so large and beige and sober on my bookshelves), pot-smoking private eye Doc Sportello would have felt at home wandering through any other book in the canon. I'm hoping that some new readers will pick up this quick marijuana-fueled trip through 1970 Los Angeles (a place where Pynchon seems very comfortable) and move on to the harder stuff, especially \\"Gravity's Rainbow,\\" which may now seem much less daunting than its reputation. (I can't help thinking about James Joyce.  How much less intimidating would his comic masterpiece \\"Ulysses\\" have seemed to many readers today if Joyce had ended his career with a simple thriller set in Dublin rather than with \\"Finnegans Wake\\"?)
B001DHXT6G|1.0|Don't read this if you are a Star Trek fan! (It may offend your sense of intelligence)<br /><br />In 1964 Gene Roddenberry created a proposed pilot for a science fiction TV series called `The Cage', starring Jeffery Hunter, it was rejected.<br /><br />In 1965 there was a reprieve, and a second pilot called `Where No Man Has Gone Before' was made starring William Shatner, it was accepted.<br /><br />\\"Space: the final frontier. These are the voyages of the starship Enterprise. Its five-year mission: to explore strange new worlds, to seek out new life and new civilizations; to boldly go where no man has gone before\\".<br /><br />From 1966 to 1969 Star Trek the TV series was aired, and then cancelled after three seasons due to poor ratings in its 10pm time slot on Friday nights, but through re-runs and syndication to achieved cult status.<br /><br />In 2006 to celebrate the 40th anniversary of Star Trek, the powers that be had done the unthinkable, they redid the original series...and how did they fare? Well, I won't bore you too much, but in short, under Mike Okuda, CBS (under CBS Digital) began restoring and updating the original series. All live-action footage was scanned in high definition from its first generation 35 mm film elements, (which included the original camera negatives) while visual effects shots have been digitally reproduced.<br /><br />Notable changes include new space shots with a CGI Enterprise, and other new models (for example, a Gorn ship is shown in Arena, which you could hardly see anyway), redone matte background shots, and other minor touches such as tidying up viewscreens (which they did not do a proper job especially the wall surrounding the Bridge viewscreen-read below for more details on this). A small number of scenes have also been recomposed, as well as adding new ones and in some cases new actors have been placed into the background of some shots (for example in A Taste of Armageddon). Not only that but every planet that the Enterprise visited was also redone, we can see this as the Enterprise orbits the planet, this in itself was a nice touch and necessary to give the original series a definitive new look.<br /><br />In addition, the opening theme music of Star Trek has been re-recorded in digital stereo. Perhaps that's why in the first season, Kirk's voice-over is hardly heard. You would need a stereo-phonic sound system to hear it clearly perhaps? In any case in season two and three, Kirk's voice-over is as clear as day.<br /><br />I believe (arguably) that the golden age of science fiction TV series was in the 1960s, 1970s and to some extent the 1980s, this was the period where imagination for such shows was at its zenith and when it comes to science fiction television series, you can't go pass Star Trek as being an icon of the genre and one of the key corner stones in science fiction influences. Star Trek itself the original series is not only the Bible for other Star Trek sequels (movies) and TV series (Star Trek: Animated, Star Trek: TNG, Voyager, Deep Space Nine and Enterprise), it is the Holy Grail that cannot be altered or changed, and if done would be sacrilege to the hard core fans of the series, any slight change would come under intense scrutiny if not done exactly right...so?<br /><br />I have viewed all three remastered seasons and herewith are my comments on notable criticisms I have observed including scenes that have not been remastered by CBS Digital...well, the ones I noticed anyway.<br /><br />\\"CBS Digital: The Remastered Series. These are the stuff-ups of `Star Trek: The Original Series'. Its two-year mission: to touch-up old scenes that they didn't and add new CGI scenes, to seek out defective negatives and series film with eyes closed for remastering; to boldly go where no computer technology which has not been effectively used has gone before\\".<br /><br />Does the above sound familiar?<br /><br />First Season Remastered Series released on November 20, 2007.<br /><br />1]The Corbomite Manoeuvre - Balok's ship the Fesarius has been redone here, but it is too detailed in extreme close up when compared to the Enterprise when both are in the same spot; it would have been better if Balok's ship had smooth round spheres (like in the original) with a very soft glow against the hard detailed Enterprise.<br /><br />2] Balance of Terror - The Romulan `Bird of Prey' was digitally redone here, but again the ship lost its blue tinge, which I believe should have remained, what were CBS Digital thinking?<br /><br />3] The Galileo Seven - We see the CGI shuttle leave the launching bay of the Enterprise, it wobbles back and forth; you think CBS Digital would make the Galileo lift smoothly out into space, bad work there.<br /><br />4] Arena - The Gorn in this episode was given eyelids. Question: Do Gorns really have eyelids? Looking at the whole episode it would have been better if the Gorn had no eyelids as in the original; I think CBS Digital should have left this alone.<br /><br />Best personal visual effects in Season One:<br /><br />1] In the episode `A Taste of Armageddon' as Kirk and party beam down to the planet Eminiar VII, we see the city in the background redone with a moving figures and a monorail no less, very well done indeed.<br /><br />Personal Note: I may have not noticed too much as far as defects/dirt and the like in this first season, as I was enjoying watching the episodes. Either CBS Digital did their job (surprise-surprise) or I wasn't looking for anything special, in any case seasons two and three made up for this.<br /><br />Second Season Remastered Series released on August 5, 2008.<br /><br />1] The Changeling - In one scene with Kirk and Spock we can actually see the black thin string that holds up Nomad.<br /><br />2] Mirror, Mirror - When Kirk talks to the leader Tharn on the Bridge's viewscreen, in the mirror universe, we see a small black dot (dirt or defect from the original negative), which should have been removed by CBS Digital, sloppy work there.<br /><br />3] The Doomsday Machine - When Decker leaves in the shuttle through the launching bay, the shuttle could've had a smoother ride out into space. CBS Digital must have rushed this one.<br /><br />4] Catspaw - In one of the final scenes showing Sylvia and Korob's true alien forms, we can still see on the left alien (puppet) the remains of the black string used to move the puppet, CBS Digital must have tried to clean this up, but have only partially succeeded, perhaps they couldn't do much here because the black string was also in front of the puppet at times and could not be digitally removed, so I will forgive them here.<br /><br />5] Journey to Babel - When Kirk is fighting Thelev, we see his neck not covered in blue, I know this is in the original, and it may be nit-picking but if the technology is available couldn't CBS Digital clean it up?, if not, I will let it pass...for now.<br /><br />6] Friday's Child -  Kirk and Spock are behind a rock waiting for a rock slide to occur, we see in the sky's background above their heads, going across the scene horizontally a very thin black line, and a vertical dark mark near Kirk's head on the right side as we view the scene. I can't believe CBS Digital missed that.<br /><br />There is also a scene where Scotty is looking at the Bridge's viewscreen searching for the destroyed freighter, the scene cuts to the Bridge's viewsrceen and we see bits of black dots and the like (an uncleaned negative) around the Bridge viewscreen. CBS Digital didn't even bother cleaning up this scene, this is just pure unprofessionalism at its worst!<br /><br />7] The Deadly Years - When the Enterprise is being attacked by the Romulans, their ships have no blue tinge again. Remember, the Romulan `Bird of Prey' is blue coloured, so why again did CBS Digital ignore this important distinction?<br /><br />8] Obsession - When Kirk uses the intercom in McCoy's sick bay, we see in close-up a couple of small black dots that CBS Digital did not clean to remove them around the intercom scene.<br /><br />9] The Trouble with Tribbles - Kirk and Spock are in the Briefing Room, when Kirk gets a call from Uhura to talk to Admiral Fitzpatrick, as Kirk turns on the intercom we see for a couple of seconds just above to the right of the intercom a small thin dark line, that CBS Digital missed.<br /><br />Also when we see a close-up of Admiral Fitzpatrick on the intercom, in the scene, there is a small black dot at the bottom left shoulder of the Admiral as we view this scene. CBS Digital again missed this one.<br /><br />10] The Immunity Syndrome - Kirk looks at the Bridge's viewscreen for the first time seeing a dark black blob; around the Bridge's viewscreen at the top and the right side, we see little black specks.<br /><br />In another same scene as above, with a closer look at the dark black blob, again an unclean negative film shot missed by CBS Digital.<br /><br />And again in another scene with the Bridge's viewscreen when it is showing black (inside the black blob), a couple of small black dots at the top and bottom of the Bridge viewscreen<br /><br />One more time; in a Bridge viewscreen scene showing the cell creature, at the top are small dark dots.<br /><br />Finally; in one of the last scenes with the Bridge viewscreen, showing space/stars, at the bottom of the Bridge viewscreen, just a couple of small black dots again.<br /><br />11] Return to Tomorrow - In the opening scene on the Bridge at Spock's station on close-up, the grey sensor device has a small black dot showing on the front face.<br /><br />After the opening credit sequence, we see a panned view of the Bridge, at the top corner of the scene there is a black dot missed by CBS Digital.<br /><br />12] Patterns of Force - In the opening scene on the Bridge, the picture of John Gill in the background has some black dots on it that has not been cleaned up, and again in close-up, the four black dots are visible.<br /><br />Also again a scene on the Bridge at Spock's station on close-up, the grey sensor device has a small black dot showing on the front face.<br /><br />While Kirk and Spock are watching the giant TV viewsrceen in the town square, on close-up, there are a couple of black dots on the right wall.<br /><br />In a scene watching John Gill's speech, in close-up of the TV viewscreen, we see a black dot at the bottom left side and at the top right side on the wall<br /><br />In the final scene, with the Bridge viewscreen shot, just at the top, a black dot can be seen.<br /><br />13] By Any Other Name - The Bridge viewscreen scene showing in close-up of `The Barrier', just at the top left corner is a very small black dot.<br /><br />14] Breads and Circuses - In the opening scene on the Bridge viewscreen close-up of the planet, we see a small black dot at the top of the viewscreen shot.<br /><br />When Kirk and company just enter the pro-council's chambers, there appears for ¬Ω a second, two white dots where the blue vase is at the bottom right of the scene. (You have to be quick to see it, or you miss it, CBS Digital certainly did)<br /><br />15] Assignment: Earth - Kirk and Spock are in the Briefing Room while Chekov can be seen on the intercom on the left side of the scene, just below the intercom on the table, you can see a small black dot.<br /><br />When Gary Seven visits the McKinley Rocket Base the scenes of the still shots of the rocket to be launched have a few black dots on them scattered about the picture, this also includes other still shots later in the episode. Why CBS Digital didn't clean these up is beyond me.<br /><br />The televised shot of the rocket being monitored at Launch Control, has a small black dot on it, as well as in a later shot/scene, a black dot can be seen on the left side in close-up.<br /><br />When Scotty is searching for Gary Seven, we see in close-up of the viewscreen, a picture of the rocket on the launch pad, and again two small dark dots on the right side of the screen.<br /><br />The televised shot of the rocket being monitored at Launch Control now in flight, in a close-up of the television screen, there are a couple of dots on the left side of this shot.<br /><br />Best personal visual effects in Season Two:<br /><br />1] In the episode `Amok Time' there are a couple of scenes added that give an extension of the exterior of the planet Vulcan. I like it.<br /><br />2] In the episode `The Doomsday Machine' the scenes showing the wreck of the USS Constellation are great.<br /><br />3] In the episode `The Trouble with Tribbles' the scenes with the CGI Space Station K7 looks real cool, well done and great work to CBS Digital.<br /><br />4] In the episode `The Immunity Syndrome' I like the effect showing the scenes where the CGI Enterprise is lit up within the zone of darkness, a rare treat viewing a different perspective of the ship.<br /><br />5] In the episode `By Any Other Name' in the opening scene, we have an excellent panoramic shot of the planet's surroundings as Kirk and company bean down to its surface.<br /><br />Third Season Remastered Series released on November 18, 2008.<br /><br />1] The Enterprise Incident - Again we see the Romulan `Bird of Prey' without its distinctive blue hull tinge.<br /><br />When Kirk is speaking to Commander Tal in the Briefing Room via the intercom, a close up shot of the commander on the intercom we see on the top left of the scene a small white jagged line.<br /><br />2] And the Children Shall Lead - Kirk and Spock are watching a video recording on the Bridge at Spock's station of Professor Starnes, when Tommy comes onto the Bridge and causes interference of the recording. As we see the scene of Kirk and Spock watching this interference, there is a very small black dot on the top blue rim (border) of the monitor/viewer.<br /><br />As the children on the Bridge watch a recording of themselves playing on the monitor/viewer, we see a very small black dot in close-up shot (on the dome section) as we watch the recording of the children playing; and again in the same scene a few moments later a small black dot on the upper right and lower left of the monitor/viewer.<br /><br />3] Spectre of the Gun - Twice in the opening Bridge scene, as we observe the Bridge's viewscreen, there are various black dots scattered around the right and bottom of the scene.<br /><br />Twice again in the opening scenes in another close-up shot of the Bridge viewscreen, when we see the Melkot communication buoy, there is a black dot at the bottom mid left and some black markings at the near upper right of these shots.<br /><br />And twice again in the opening scenes on the Bridge viewscreen, showing the Melkot communication buoy, a couple of very small black dots are showing.<br /><br />All in all there are at least six scenes here in the opening teaser with the Melkot communication buoy that need touch-ups.<br /><br />In the final Bridge scenes with the Melkot communication buoy, before the Melkotian appears, we see some black dots scattered around the Bridge viewscreen.<br /><br />4] Day of the Dove - As the scene opens and continuing with Chekov leaving the turbo-lift and moving through the corridor to find Klingons to kill; there are a few very small black dots and markings about the scene. (You have to have this scene in slow motion to see the defects, frame by frame).<br /><br />I have also noticed that this episode is grainy in various scenes, if this is supposed to be re-digitally done, why is this episode not crisp and clear?<br /><br />Also I have noticed the occasional white/black dot throughout this episode, especially sometimes where there is a scene with the alien entity, example: the final engineering scenes at the end of the episode.<br /><br />5] For the World is Hollow and I have Touched the Sky - While Kirk and Spock are beaming down in the room where Natira is with McCoy, who is lying unconscious after the oracle's implant attack. We see as the two men are beaming in, just to the left on the red pale floor, there is a faint grey spot, doing the same, appearing with the effect.<br /><br />6] The Tholian Web - On the Bridge as Sulu tells Scott the `Defiant' is disappearing, we have a shot of the ship on the Bridge viewscreen, at the bottom left of this scene we see a couple of black dots, which appears again in another same scene.<br /><br />On the Bridge viewscreen showing for the first and second time the Tholian ship, we see on the top left area, a very small black dot and then again later, before the Tholian ship is fired upon.<br /><br />On the first and second Bridge viewscreen scene showing the Tholian commander, we have a very small black dot at the bottom middle of this shot.<br /><br />In another scene with the Tholian commander, a couple of very small black dots, one at the top and bottom of the Bridge viewscreen.<br /><br />While Spock and McCoy watch Kirk's message on the intercom, on a close-up shot of Kirk, just to the right of the intercom on its rim, there is a black smudge; this happens again later in a scene when Spock is talking to Scott about the next interphase.<br /><br />In one of the final scenes, on the Bridge viewscreen showing Kirk, there is a small black dot at the top right of this shot.<br /><br />7] Wink of an Eye - In the opening teaser as McCoy watches Compton disappear, we see for ¬Ω a second very small black dots accompanying this effect.<br /><br />When Deela and Kirk first meet on the Bridge, they have a scene near the turbo-lift; the red alert light that is flashing has a small white dot near it.<br /><br />When Spock looks at his station's viewer at Compton's disappearance, there are a few black dots scattered around the close-up scene of the viewer.<br /><br />Again when Spock is watching his viewer of the Scalosian message speeding up, there is again very small black dots in a close-up scene of the viewer, this continues again as Spock watches his viewer.<br /><br />8] The Empath - In the opening teaser, Kirk, Spock and McCoy are watching a recording of the scientists via the intercom viewer, thus there is a black dot at the upper right of the close-up scene and also we have the same dark smudge, I reported on previous episodes. Looks like the same intercom shot/still was used for close-ups.<br /><br />Also as we watch the intercom viewer, while we notice Ozaba covering his ears, because of the weird sound, you can see a vertical thin dark line above him before he disappears.<br /><br />9] Whom Gods Destroy - As Spock/Garth stuns the Tellarite in the corridor to help him and Kirk escape, there is a white dot on the red/orange door to the left as Spock/Garth fires his phaser.<br /><br />10] Let That Be Your Last Battlefield - When Kirk is informed by Chekov of an alien ship being detected; we see the Bridge viewscreen close-up with various black dots around the Bridge viewscreen, this happens five times within the whole Bridge scene.<br /><br />As Kirk talks Lokai on the Bridge after his fight with Bele on close-up of Lokai just to the left near the red alert light on the wall for ¬Ω a second there is a white dot.<br /><br />On the Bridge viewscreen on the first close-up of the planet Cheron again there are various black dots around this shot; this happens again in a later scene.<br /><br />A Bridge scene close-up shot of Lokai and Bele standing beside each other, there is a black dot showing on Lokai's chest. (How CBS Digital could have missed a so obvious dirt mark is beyond me)<br /><br />Again in another close-up shot of the planet Cheron on the Bridge viewscreen, we see various small black dots around this scene.<br /><br />11] The Mark of Gideon - In the opening teaser as Spock beams down Kirk, as the beaming takes place, just to the left of the shot parallel to Kirk's waist, is a black dot and a thin black hair-line mark.<br /><br />As Kirk is on the Bridge alone, he looks at the Bridge viewscreen,and sees the planet Gideon, in this shot like so many others there are various black dots accompanying this scene, which happens twice.<br /><br />As Spock talks to Hodin via the Bridge viewscreen, in close-up there are a couple of black dots scattered around this scene, which happens five times.<br /><br />In a Bridge viewscreen close-up shot, as Krodak dematerialises, again there are black dots scattered around this shot.<br /><br />In the next Bridge viewscreen close-up of Hodin, there are black dots scattered around this scene which happens twice.<br /><br />Bridge scene with Kirk and Odona in close-up, when they are facing each other, there is a white dot in the middle top of this shot for ¬Ω a second.<br /><br />The second and third scene close-up of the Bridge viewscreen showing many green faces, there are scattered black dots around these shots.<br /><br />As Spock talks to Admiral Fitzgerald on the Bridge viewscreen, we see quite a few black dots scattered around this shot, this scene happens at least nine times while Spock is talking to the Admiral and is one of the worst unclean series of scenes I've seen that has not been fixed up.<br /><br />As Kirk, Spock and Odona beam up to the Enterprise, you can just see some black markings on Kirk's face.<br /><br />As Odona talks to Kirk in the sick bay, there is a close-up shot of her and just to the left-you have to be quick, a small light blue mark can be seen on the wall for ¬Ω a second in the background<br /><br />12] The Lights of Zetar - In a Bridge viewscreen scene in close-up of the aft view of the space entity following the Enterprise, below this scene we see a couple of small black dots; also in the next same scene situation, there is a small black dot on the left and top of this shot.<br /><br />And again in the following same scene, a couple of black dots in the lower left corner of this shot, this happens about four times.<br /><br />Semi-Bridge viewscreen scene showing the alien entity with Sulu's back to us, as he reports on the alien, for ¬Ω a second near the top of the scene there is a white dot.<br /><br />Looks like we have our favourite intercom shot with the black smudge on the right grey border/rim, as we see Mira floating in the de-COM pressure chamber, this happens three times.<br /><br />13] Requiem for Methuselah - When Kirk, Spock and McCoy beam down on Mr. Flint's planet, they are attacked by M4, a close-up of M4, there is a small black dot on the top right of this scene.<br /><br />When Kirk looks at the miniature Enterprise, the scene in close-up as Kirk's face is on the Bridge viewscreen, thus in the Bridge scene there are various black dots around this shot which happens three times.<br /><br />14] The Savage Curtain - In the opening teaser, in close-up of the Bridge viewscreen when Lincoln first appears, there are a few scattered black dots at the top of this scene.<br /><br />Best personal visual effects in Season Three:<br /><br />1] In the episode `Requiem for Methuselah' we have a shot of Mr. Flint's unique residence with the two moons in the background; brilliant architecture!<br /><br />2] In the episode `The Way to Eden' when Kirk, Spock, McCoy and Chekov beam down to the planet Eden, a short panoramic scene of Eden is shown; a beautiful shot indeed.<br /><br />3] In the episode `The Cloud Minders' brief shots in close-up of the city of Stratos are well done.<br /><br />From the above as you can see there are a lot of scenes/shots (Bridge viewscreen shots/scenes especially) that need to be cleaned/touched up (a lot of dirty black dots/marks from the negatives) to make this a remastered series whole, so why didn't CBS Digital do so? (No, I don't want to hear that they couldn't and that they didn't have the technology to fix it, could it be they weren't paid enough?) You got me, perhaps we should ask them, then again perhaps they are too embarrassed to admit they stuffed it up, So any mistakes it's unbelievable, I can't understand whythey didn't do a proper job-can you? Why are there so many scenes/frames not touched up and/or fixed? We do have the technology to repair/patch up these age old defects-so why wasn't it done?<br /><br />Also especially in season two/three including the opening credit sequence and in other shots I noticed when there is a close-up of the CGI Enterprise orbiting a planet its movement across the scene has a slight stop-start effect, doubtless a CGI glitch-which shouldn't be-am I right? Or it may be my DVD operating system? Now that I notice, it's so distracting, annoying and such a nuisance. No smooth glide across the screen-how come?<br /><br />Another thing I noticed which I don't like is when we see the aft view through the Bridge's viewscreen, (especially in the first season and occasionally in the second/third season) when the Enterprise moves away from a planet for example, we see the ship's two nacelles, I find this distracting, and really not essential as we can see clearly the Enterprise moving away from the planet and or object (for example the planet getting smaller, the fans and the viewers are not that dum-are they?).<br /><br />A Major Remastered Blunder:<br /><br />Well I don't believe it, but the remastered series has a major flaw/blunder, it's so obvious, I don't know how CBS Digital could have missed it, it is so unforgivable I am ashamed even to mention it; and it is in all the episodes, in all the three seasons. The pain of it all, but having redone the Star Trek episodes as a whole, one part has been neglected, which should have been remastered also, why it wasn't is a mystery.<br /><br />The blunder-the end episode credit sequence, with the credits not withstanding, it is the background stills that have NOT been replaced with remastered stills, and this is even more evident with shots of the Un-CGI Enterprise. If one is going to redo and do justice to a cult sci-fi show, you need to do it all the way from the beginning to the end and not just redo two thirds of the episode. It is annoying to watch a remastered episode and to have it ruined by an un-remastered end credit sequence. CBS Digital have done justice to the beginning of the show, but have done nothing at its end-WHY? Perhaps CBS Digital didn't because they thought that no one would bother with watching the end credits, and so they could neglect that part of the episode and no one would notice-well I certainly did, and it's bad.<br /><br />This neglect of the end credit sequence is totally unprofessional if you ask me, watching the extras on the DVD's CBS Digital came across with pride in redoing the show and its episodes, am I missing something? I would even accept remastered close-to-different still shots, just to make a distinction between the original and remastered series-that would work-but CBS Digital obviously didn't have the brains to even think about that.<br /><br />Another thing that should have been added to this DVD set are booklets on the episodes, the title, a still shot, a description of the story, the guest stars and what was done to the remastered episode; this in itself would be a great addition to the DVDs instead of having those plastic inserts on the cheap. That's one thing missing with DVD movies and TV series as a whole, no decent booklet with your purchase.<br /><br />A final word:<br /><br />Hey don't get me wrong, I like Star Trek, it's one of my favourite shows, I like watching the episodes, with Kirk and company and their adventures in space, its great fun; I think its science fiction at its best, so no complaints there. Now I would like to give the remastered series five stars-but I can't, with the mistakes mentioned including the end credit sequence and un-remastered background stills in all three seasons, and even scenes which in my mind have not been digitally perfected, it is impossible to do so until these errors are corrected. This is definitely not a remastered series to be proud of, CBS Digital did not go frameby frame to eliminate errors and correct the original negatives that showed them to improve the series quality. So why didn't they?<br /><br />If you want to purchase the remastered series to start your Star Trek collection to see what has been added and or fixed (if anything), please do so with my blessing, (but be warned) and or if you are a sci-fi buff like me, or a Star Trek fan/collector, it would be wise to get the un-remastered series as well, which is exactly what I have done-yes I know the un-remastered series will have all the mistakes/dirt/uncleaned negatives, but that's ok because I know all that, but this remastered series should have remedied all of this-right? Instead it is such a mess, I could almost cry, the Holy Grail that is Star Trek has been desecrated and one of its followers/believers is not happy.<br /><br />Mike and his visual effects team have done a great job, but it is not excellent, there are still flaws and CBS Digital missed a lot, the ones I mentioned are just what I spotted in the series-maybe there's more that I missed? If this is supposed to a remastered series, then the job isn't finished yet, Mike and the boys have shown great talent, but they also have shown great unprofessional talent and laziness to cut corners and be paid for their sloppy services and expertise, so get back to the so-called drawing board and fix the mistakes. If you are going to do the job, do it properly, or don't do it at all.<br /><br />Remember this review is not what CBS Digital has done right to improve the series, it is to show what CBS Digital has not done right to make it better.<br /><br />Special thanks to Wikipedia for additional information and research for this review.<br /><br />Live Long...and Prosper. Looks like we have our favourite intercom shot with the black smudge on the right grey border/rim, as we see Mira floating in the de-COM pressure chamber, this happens three times.      13] Requiem for Methuselah - When Kirk, Spock and McCoy beam down on Mr. Flint's planet, they are attacked by M4, a close-up of M4, there is a small black dot on the top right of this scene.    When Kirk looks at the miniature Enterprise, the scene in close-up as Kirk's face is on the Bridge viewscreen, thus in the Bridge scene there are various black dots around this shot which happens three times.    14] The Savage Curtain - In the opening teaser, in close-up of the Bridge viewscreen when Lincoln firstappears, there are a few scattered black dots at the top of this scene.     Best personal visual effects in Season Three:     1] In the episode `Requiem for Methuselah' we have a shot of Mr. Flint's unique residence with the two moons in the background; brilliant architecture!     2] In the episode `The Way to Eden' when Kirk, Spock, McCoy and Chekov beam down to the planet Eden, a short panoramic scene of Eden is shown; a beautiful shot indeed.    3] In the episode `The Cloud Minders' brief shots in close-up of the city of Stratos are well done.    From the above as you can see there are a lot of scenes/shots (Bridge viewscreen shots/scenes especially) that need to be cleaned/touched up (a lot of dirty black dots/marks from the negatives) to make this a remastered series whole, so why didn't CBS Digital do so? (No, I don't want to hear that they couldn't and that they didn't have the technology to fix it, could it be they weren't paid enough?) You got me, perhaps we should ask them, then again perhaps they are too embarrassed to admit they stuffed it up, So any mistakes it's unbelievable, I can't understand why they didn't do a proper job-can you? Why are there so many scenes/frames not touched up and/or fixed? We do have the technology to repair/patch up these age old defects-so why wasn't it done?     Also especially in season two/three including the opening credit sequence and in other shots I noticed when there is a close-up of the CGI Enterprise orbiting a planet its movement across the scene has a slight stop-start effect, doubtless a CGI glitch-which shouldn't be-am I right? Or it may be my DVD operating system? Now that I notice, it's so distracting, annoying and such a nuisance. No smooth glide across the screen-how come?    Another thing I noticed which I don't like is when we see the aft view through the Bridge's viewscreen, (especially in the first season and occasionally in the second/third season) when the Enterprise moves away from a planet for example, we see the ship's two nacelles, I find this distracting, and really not essential as we can see clearly the Enterprise moving away from the planet and or object (for example the planet getting smaller, the fans and the viewers are not that dum-are they?).    A Major Remastered Blunder:    Well I don't believe it, but the remastered series has a major flaw/blunder, it's so obvious, I don't know how CBS Digital could have missed it, it is so unforgivable I am ashamed even to mention it; and it is in all the episodes, in all the three seasons. The pain of it all, but having redone the Star Trek episodes as a whole, one part has been neglected, which should have been remastered also, why it wasn't is a mystery.     The blunder-the end episode credit sequence, with the credits not withstanding, it is the background stills that have NOT been replaced with remastered stills, and this is even more evident with shots of the Un-CGI Enterprise. If one is going to redo and do justice to a cult sci-fi show, you need to do it all the way from the beginning to the end and not just redo two thirds of the episode. It is annoying to watch a remastered episode and to have it ruined by an un-remastered end credit sequence. CBS Digital have done justice to the beginning of the show, but have done nothing at its end-WHY? Perhaps CBS Digital didn't because they thought that no one would bother with watching the end credits, and so they could neglect that part of the episode and no one would notice-well I certainly did, and it's bad.    This neglect of the end credit sequence is totally unprofessional if you ask me, watching the extras on the DVD's CBS Digital came across with pride in redoing the show and its episodes, am I missing something? I would even accept remastered close-to-different still shots, just to make a distinction between the original and remastered series-that would work-but CBS Digital obviously didn't have the brains to even think about that.    Another thing thatshould have been added to this DVD set are booklets on the episodes, the title, a still shot, a description of the story, the guest stars and what was done to the remastered episode; this in itself would be a great addition to the DVDs instead of having those plastic inserts on the cheap. That's one thing missing with DVD movies and TV series as a whole, no decent booklet with your purchase.    A final word:    Hey don't get me wrong, I like Star Trek, it's one of my favourite shows, I like watching the episodes, with Kirk and company and their adventures in space, its great fun; I think its science fiction at its best, so no complaints there. Now I would like to give the remastered series five stars-but I can't, with the mistakes mentioned including the end credit sequence and un-remastered background stills in all three seasons, and even scenes which in my mind have not been digitally perfected, it is impossible to do so until these errors are corrected. This is definitely not a remastered series to be proud of, CBS Digital did not go frame by frame to eliminate errors and correct the original negatives that showed them to improve the series quality. So why didn't they?    If you want to purchase the remastered series to start your Star Trek collection to see what has been added and or fixed (if anything), please do so with my blessing, (but be warned) and or if you are a sci-fi buff like me, or a Star Trek fan/collector, it would be wise to get the un-remastered series as well, which is exactly what I have done-yes I know the un-remastered series will have all the mistakes/dirt/uncleaned negatives, but that's ok because I know all that, but this remastered series should have remedied all of this-right? Instead it is such a mess, I could almost cry, the Holy Grail that is Star Trek has been desecrated and one of its followers/believers is not happy.     Mike and his visual effects team have done a great job, but it is not excellent, there are still flaws and CBSDigital missed a lot, the ones I mentioned are just what I spotted in the series-maybe there's more that I missed? If this is supposed to a remastered series, then the job isn't finished yet, Mike and the boys have shown great talent, but they also have shown great unprofessional talent and laziness to cut corners and be paid for their sloppy services and expertise, so get back to the so-called drawing board and fix the mistakes. If you are going to do the job, do it properly, or don't do it at all.     Remember this review is not what CBS Digital has done right to improve the series, it is to show what CBS Digital has not done right to make it better.    Special thanks to Wikipedia for additional information and research for this review.    Live Long...and Prosper. (Well for some of us anyway)

0765360969|5.0|Mistborn is part Epic Fantasy and part Superhero Origin Story.  Taking place in a unique world, Mistborn delivers action, adventure, and drama.     Plot:  An omnipotent lord rules the land with brutality and terror.  Armed soldiers take joy in beating a helpless population into submission.  Magic wielding Inquisitors strike fear into their hearts through torture and death.  Wealthy aristocratic houses attempt to outmaneuver each other politically and economically.  The Skaa, a once proud race, have been conquered, enslaved, and worked to death in slums, plantations, and mines.  But hope lies in the mists as rebels plan a revolution.      World:  Brandon Sanderson does an excellent job creating and building an exciting new Fantasy World complete with its own magic system based on consuming metals.  In the day, ash falls from blood red skies.  At night, the land is engulfed in darkness and mist.  Mistwraiths haunt the lands at night, and the Inquisitors roam the city streets in the day.  Those who are Mistborne use a magic system called Allomancy and consuming types of metal gives them powers.  Pewter enhances physical abilities, Tin enhances perception, Steel pushes metals with tremendous force...  Imagine a coin going right through someone's head.  This book is worth reading based on the unique universe and magic system alone.  The book also features a useful glossary at the end that explains the types of mages and magic.    Characters:  The main character is a street urchin named Vin.  She's likeable, clever, and tough.  For the most part, the characters are well written.  There are some that could use more screen time and the dialogue could have been a bit better at times.  But overall, they're good.      Action:  This book contains some very unique action scenes that may be described as a cross between The Matrix and The X-Men set in a fantasy universe.  There are some fairly long breaks in the action, but when there is action, it's great.    Balls:  This book has Balls; the expensive, fancy dress, snooty, dancing kind.  This is where the political aristocratic house warfare takes place.  These chapters could be annoying for angsty fantasy fans that want pure action.  These scenes slow the pacing of the book just a bit.  But if you're mature enough to enjoy a glass of wine, you'll like these scenes.  To the angsty action fans (like me), they're not so bad and trust me; you'll really want to get to the end of this book!    Overall:  This is a refreshingly original fantasy adventure with action, subterfuge, and magic.  I'd give it a 4.5 outta 5!    If you like fantasy books that have world building, originality, action, and BALLS pick this one up!  You'll enjoy it!    If you want traditional fantasy with elves, dragons, castles, knights on a quest, or you aren't a fan of balls, then you can avoid this one.    (But you'd still probably enjoy it, if you gave it a shot.)

The Tarahumara are fascinating people.  They survive on drinking corn beer and eating corn gruel and vegetables. Despite their diet, they are amazing athletes who can run like the wind. Running is a competitive sport, but it is an activity that brings people together in this book, and I love that.<br /><br />McDougall spends a lot of time talking about things like the physiology of what makes human beings good runners.  He also talks about the myth of wearing new shoes.  These are interesting subjects and a fascinating book about running.

1423332865|4.0|Loving Frank by Nancy Horan is a work of fiction. The author is a former journalist, who resides in Oak Park, Illinois, which is home to the largest collection of Frank Lloyd Wright architecture. This ambitious debut novel is the result of seven years of research.<br /><br />In the early 1900's Frank Lloyd Wright and Mamah Borthwick Cheny began a clandestine love affair. The two met when Mamah and her husband Edwin, commissioned Wright to design a new home for the two of them.<br /><br />Mamah, who could be described as an intellectual feminist, followed her heart, and left her husband and children to be with Wright, the man she loved. Mamah's unmarried sister moved in to care for her sister's two children.<br /><br />Wright, married and the father of six children himself, had a wife who refused to give him a divorce.<br /><br />Their scandalous relationship, something which would seem almost commonplace by today's standards, shocked Chicago.<br /><br />A fascinating historical account of these individuals, and their relationship that ended in disaster. The beautiful details of architectural designs will leave an imprint in your mind. The ending left me speechless. ( I had not read any details about this book beforehand). The audio book was great, but this is another one of those books that I might have preferred reading the printed edition a bit more. This book left me curious to know exactly what was fact and what was fiction. I plan to read a bit more to satisfy my curiosity. RECOMMENDED

Second, and more significantly, the packaging is terrible (delete another star).  Not sure who thought it was a good idea to include a telescoping box that doesn't fit on most shelves: IT'S NOT!  Further, and this strains credibility, nowhere in the set is there any indication of which episodes are on which discs - beyond deliniating the different seasons. Without disc contents, finding a particular episode with current bluray player load speeds is tedious.  Sure, you can print out your own 'cue cards', but on a $200 set the ommission is significant.
0141182504|5.0|Alexander Pope's translation (c. 1720) of the Iliad.  Now there's a preposterously highblown translation that many would think needed to be redone for the modern age.<br /><br />But Stuart Gilbert's masterful translation of \\"L'etranger\\" from 1946 is for me perfect and, heck, still easily available.  There was nothing that needed to be reworked about that:  pace Laredo and Ward, it's still fresh and relevant.<br /><br />Further, Gilbert's rendering has the kind of spare grace that conveys the flavor of the original much better than Joseph Laredo's, arguably conveying, by means of its overall icy tone, Mersault's remote demeanor much more convincingly.  The final phrase, \\"greet me with howls of execration\\" is much more chillingly rendered there than here, in Laredo's pedestrian and forgettable \\"greet me with cries of hatred.\\"

Coleman begins a strange affair with an aimless woman (Nicole Kidman) half his age, who has had a tragic past and isn't ready to return his love.<br /><br />For me, this strange little movie was doomed from the start, when the big finish is shown right away.  The rest of the story is shown in choppy, anti-climactic flashbacks (often out of order) which didn't allow for any build-up in tension or sympathy for the main character, Coleman.  As a young man from New Jersey, he's played by Wentworth Miller who is quite charismatic and likeable, but looked and sounded nothing like the Welsh-accented adult Coleman (who sometimes appeared to channel a leering Hannibal Lector).  Hopkins is so horribly miscast in this role that it's impossible to buy the racially-charged plot.  Kidman was also completely wrong for this movie; her innate grace and elegance couldn't be hidden by a messy hairdo and I never bought her as an illiterate custodian.  Her graphic love scenes with Hopkins were more creepy than romantic.<br /><br />There is so much personal tragedy among the main characters  - including Gary Sinise who plays a troubled writer and Ed Harris as a crazed Vietnam vet - and yet the movie misfires completely and I felt no connection with them or the whole premise of injustice.  Afterward, I was left shaking my head at this surprising mess of a movie and just amazed that so much talent couldn't save it.

0887306667|4.0|I picked up this book at the recommendation of a friend of mine. He told me that it was absolutely mandatory that I read this book immediately because I am in the process of starting a business. The \\"Laws\\" outlined in The 22 Immutable Laws of Marketing, by Al Ries & Jack Trout, are interesting and have a few gems, but the book is definitely outdated. Originally published in 1993, Ries and Trout identify many fledgling companies and predict their ultimate downfall. For instance:    \\"Microsoft is the leader in personal computer operating systems, but it trails the leaders in each of the following major categories: spreadsheets (Lotus is the leader), word processing (WordPerfect is the leader), and business graphics (Harvard Graphics from SPC Software Publishing is the leader).    [...]    There are ominous signs of softness in Microsoft's strategy. The Economist reported in early 1992, \\"Mr. Gates is putting together a range of products, based on a common core of technology, that will compete across virtually the whole of the software industry: from big computers to small ones, and from operating systems in the information engine-room to graphics programs that draw every picture for executives. Nobody in the software industry has yet managed a venture of that complexity - though IBM has tried and failed.\\"    When you try to be all things to all people, you inevitably wind up in trouble. \\"I'd rather be strong somewhere, \\"said one manager, \\"than weak everywhere.\\"    Clearly, Microsoft is now the leader not only in spreadsheets (Microsoft Excel) and word processing (Microsoft Word), but also nearly all facets of the user interface of personal and business computers. Additionally, Microsoft is a significant player in servers, mobile smart phones, search engines, among many others. Google didn't even exist at the time 22 Laws was written, but brand extension has worked remarkably well for Larry Page and Sergey Brin.  (One could argue that Microsoft and Google created theirown categories.  If that is the case, I believe the \\"line extension\\" argument would still be  voided.)    This example identifies a core weakness in the book: it was written before the rise of the internet age. Prior to the internet really taking off, marketing was a completely different animal. It cost a lot of money to market any product. It cost a lot of money to develop and launch a product (take a look at Inc Magazine's feature \\"The Day My Industry Died\\" to see a few examples of how the cost of business has plummeted since the early days of the internet). Lastly, it took a lot of money and time to grow a company. It was difficult to have the explosive growth that was experienced on a large scale late last century and early this decade.

Hopefully having her name on the marquee will draw in viewers who otherwise might have missed this exciting psychological thriller.    Fans of \\"The Wire\\" and \\"The Office\\" are already familiar with the talents of Idris Elba.  The twist in this film that makes it different from \\"Fatal Attraction\\" is that Elba's husband character is entirely innocent of any extra-marital activity, unlike Michael Douglas in \\"Fatal Attraction.\\"  Even though the Douglas character did not deserve the troubles that he faced in that earlier film, you always knew that he was responsible for them due to his choice to be unfaithful to his wife.       In this film, to his credit Idris Elba, rejects the advances of the persistent Ali Larter's character on numerous occasions.  Sure, he could have told his wife about the initial advances of the obsessed temp and perhaps saved himself some of the strains to his marriage but such would have done nothing to affect the behavior of the obsessed woman who was not going to give up her quest.  Elba's husband was simply in an impossible situation.  Telling his wife, co-workers, and even the police was not going to get him out of the box that he found himself in.      I found Ali Larter's performance to be even more frightening than Glenn Close's in \\"Fatal Attraction\\" since unlike Close, she exhibited no outward visible manifestations of a mental illness.  A casual observer in the office might have noticed her interest and attraction to the Elba character, but who would have suspected the sort of obsessive behavior that she was capable of once she was outside of the office environment?    Although the film's ultimate conclusion was fairly predictable, it was exciting and satisfying.  If you enjoy films like \\"Fatal Attraction,\\" \\"The Hand That Rocks the Cradle,\\" \\"Basic Instinct\\" and \\"Disclosure,\\" watching this one would be a great way to spend an evening.

0765356139|4.0|The Final Empire has fragmented into numerous squabbling bandit kingdoms and rebel states. Elend Venture has taken control of the former capital, Luthadel, aided by Vin, a powerful Mistborn, and the other leaders of the rebellion. But Elend's idealistic dreams of a democratic government are sorely tested when two other rulers lay claim to the city and arrive to besiege it.    Meanwhile, the Terris Keeper, Sazed, is worried by reports of the return of a deadly form of the mists that appear at night, and begins an investigation into the prophecies that led to the Lord Ruler gaining power, searching for clues as to the location of the Well of Ascension, the only power in the world that might save it from destruction...    Picking up where The Final Empire left off, The Well of Ascension sees a marked change in pace in the development of the Mistborn series. The first book was a bit of a caper story mixed in with a traditional 'rebelling against the evil ruler' narrative with a great magic system on top. Book 2 now sees the former rebels coping themselves with the pressures of governance. Elend, a rather thin character in the first book, becomes a lot more interesting in this volume as his former idealism clashes with an increasingly cynical outlook brought about by events. There's also a lessening of focus on Vin. Whilst still the central character, Elend and Sazed come much more to the fore in this novel as well. There's also a new Mistborn character, Zane, who enters the story and provides an effective sparring partner for Vin. Sanderson's worldbuilding also comes on a lot in this book, with a logical development of his metal-based magic system.    On the minus side, the change in narrative style means a slackening of the pace. There's a lot of talk and intrigue in this book, although it isn't entirely convincing and leads to a static pace as the various factions are engaged in a stand-off for most of the story, no one side able to move without being defeated by theothers. This makes for a slightly less engaging story than the first book.    However, in the last 200 pages or so Sanderson suddenly turns everything up to 11. All hell breaks loose and as well as featuring major battles there are a series of stunning revelations about the prophecies that our characters have been following so far. The prophecy is a particularly annoying staple of epic fantasy literature but Sanderson's treatment of it at the end of this book is fascinating, making for a great twist ending.    The Well of Ascension (****) takes a while to get going, but decent character development keeps things ticking over until the action and revelation-packed finale. The novel is available now in the USA and will be published on 10 December 2009 by Gollancz in the UK.

0307454541|4.0|\\"The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo\\" is part traditional detective story and part high-tech hacker suspense.  Mikael Blomkvist, an investigative reporter who plays the part of the traditional middle-aged detective type,  and Lisbeth Salander, a young, antisocial hacker girl who follows in the mold of the latest literary trend towards eccentric detectives, team up to try to solve a traditional murder case and to foil a rich financial gangster at the same time.  I found the murder portion of this book extremely well written and suspenseful.  On the other hand, the financial \\"investigations\\" seemed to lack a lot of suspense that the murder sequence did due to how easily Lisbeth handles them.  It was obvious to me that Larsson spent much of his life reading murder mysteries, and he seemed to take many of the best elements from them in the murder portion on the book, and it was a shame that the financial investigation section of the book felt rushed and unsatisfying, staining an otherwise excellent book.  I didn't find Salander to be a particularly compelling character, and became more and more annoyed as she became more of a prodigy throughout the book.  By the end of it, one is convinced that she could probably take over the entire world if she wanted to.  Blomkvist was a much more likable and believable character, although Larsson seems to spend a great deal of time showing how sexually open and liberated he is by involving him with multiple sexual partners.  Nevertheless, despite these qualms, Larsson has an excellent way with words and at certain points in the story it is very hard to put down the book as the suspense builds.  By putting a deep theme in his book involving men and women and violence, Larsson goes a step above most crime writers out there today.  Overall, \\"The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo\\" was a fulfilling but not perfect read that will entertain even the most discriminating readers out there.

B000002I25|5.0|Before The Doors released their debut album in 1967, rock and roll at that time was starting to sound more and more the same and just \\"typical\\" or run-of-the-mill.  In other words, pioneers and trailblazers were in short supply.  The Doors shook things up when they emerged on the scene playing at clubs in Los Angeles in 1965 and 1966.  They were pioneers or \\"radicals\\" because of their unique sound.  A bottleneck guitar player (Robbie Krieger) who used his fingernails instead of a pick, a jazz drummer (John Densmore), an organ player (Ray Manzarek) who played both the organ and organ bass at the same time, and an out-of-control singer (Jim Morrison) who was a poet and wrote poetic lyrics and was a student of film and was college educated, as Ray Manzarek was, also.<br /><br />A unique lineup of musicians formed one of the greatest rock bands of all time, The Doors.<br /><br />The Doors had no regular bass player, so Ray Manzarek played keyboard bass on this debut album, and also in concert.  On later albums, session bass players were used in the studio, but during concerts the bass was provided by Manzarek's organ bass.  The debut album was recorded almost all live - the band would play and Morrison would sing at the same time, so virtually every song was a one-shot recording, if you will.  This album contains some classic songs such as Break On Through (To The Other Side), Soul Kitchen, The Crystal Ship, Twentieth Century Fox, Alabama Song (Whiskey Bar), Light My Fire, Back Door Man, I Looked At You, End Of The Night, Take It As It Comes, and the 11 minute epic, The End.  I named the whole album!<br /><br />The revolutionary sound of The Doors is what made them trailblazers.  An eerie organ, keyboard bass, bottleneck guitar playing, jazz drumming, and the unique vocals and poetic lyrics of Jim Morrison.  What's not to like?  If you like bands that are different and think outside the box and don't fall into the same category as everyone else, give The Doors and their debut album a listen.  They have remained my second favorite band behind Motley Crue.  They might become one of your favorites if you haven't heard them before.They have remained my second favorite band behind Motley Crue.  They might become one of your favorites if you haven't heard them before.

They were pioneers or \\"radicals\\" because of their unique sound. A bottleneck guitar player (Robbie Krieger) who used his fingernails instead of a pick, a jazz drummer (John Densmore), an organ player (Ray Manzarek) who played both the organ and organ bass at the same time, and an out-of-control singer (Jim Morrison) who was a poet and wrote poetic lyrics and was a student of film and was college educated, as Ray Manzarek was, also.<br /><br />A unique lineup of musicians formed one of the greatest rock bands of all time, The Doors.<br /><br />The Doors had no regular bass player, so Ray Manzarek played keyboard bass on this debut album, and also in concert. Indian Summer later appeared on 1970's Morrison Hotel.<br /><br />In addition, the songs on this 2007 version of the debut album are remastered with advanced resolution to sound crisper and clearer.  Morrison's voice is a little more in the background with the keyboard and drums sounding more upfront.  One of the unique things about this album is the song Light My Fire being at the correct speed.  It is faster, which is how it was supposed to be. B000002UJQ|2.0|Within the album Ok Computer there are two songs titled Airbag and The Tourist.  It is obvious that Radiohead is attempting to spread a message of what their songs are about.  The artwork inside the CD case itself is a meticulous portrayal of their songs, with the two aforementioned songs being the most intricately expressed by the artwork.  In Airbag there seems to be a strong connection between an idea of incarnation and the self-proclaimed Evangelical Christians' concept of being born again -- although this belief of being born again is shared by most, if not all, of those who confess a belief in Christianity; however, the interpretations of how to obtain this are disputed.  In The Tourist, the resounding theme is to \\"slow down.\\"   Pictures of planes, subways, and a picture of Seattle with planes and helicopters hovering over it are expressive of a world that is ever moving and never resting.  These songs, coupled with the artwork, attempt to promote the message of Radiohead by stirring emotions and abstraction.   Airbag repeats the phrase \\"I am born again\\" three times.  It of course brings to mind, at least to anyone raised in or knowledgeable of American culture, the close association of these four words with Christianity.  However, when people who claim to be Christians use this phrase, they typically mean that they have accepted Jesus as their lord and salvation from a second death, but Radiohead is not embracing this idea literally expressed by the words because the song states that he has come back as the matter between the stars (interstellar), a strong force with a knife (jackknifed juggernaut), a neon sign, and finally an entity inside a fast German car.  The Christian principal overtone is confirmed in the artwork of the CD.  There is a statue, perhaps a representation of Jesus, with his hand held out towards a circular object (most likely a representation of some planet) and a young couple dressed up with a baby in their arms looking upward at the statue.  Below the statue's neck is a drawing of an airport path with \\"take off\\" references.  The airport drawing ties into the rest of the CD that is expressive of our modern times.  It is difficult to determine if Radiohead is mocking these Christian principles, or that they believe these principles have psychological value (e.g. there is a picture of a man looking outside a plane with fire and the brief quotation above) -- perhaps it is to be left to the listener and viewer of the song and artwork.  Regardless of the interpretation one may take from this song, it is clear that Radiohead expected one to be thinking of the modern world as viewed through Christian principles.   The Tourist is all about life going too fast.  Radiohead seems to reiterate this by the pictures in the CD.  The pictures immediately following the song are of a subway system and people running and waiting for it, a plane, and a city that has helicopters landed and one flying above the city.  There are the words \\"by a fast-track career that ...modern world\\" which indicates that society has become so engrossed in work, that it has forgotten to slow down, reflect on things that are important, and take time out to enjoy life.  The song ends with \\"idiot, slow down, slow down.\\"  Surely, this is a warning for people in the industrial world to look at what they are missing as they hurry about their business.  The idea that \\"life is precious\\" may perhaps be losing its profoundness with many.  It does often seem as though we are just rats running through a maze, as the clich√© goes, and that society is only concerned in getting a job done, making money, getting another job done and repeating this endless circle.  The Tourist expresses what many are guilty of -- society gets angry when it is overcharged, but little to no tinge of anger is felt as a host of legal and moral injustices are committed.  A view point from this artwork and song is that this fast track, career oriented world has lost its focus and is no longer enjoying life and pursuing to make it better, because we are simply too busy rushing to work, making money, and then repeating the cycle.  It seems to be the warning of Radiohead that we are all just tourists, and that our days are few -- should we spend them running a \\"rat race?\\"      Work Cited  Radiohead.  \\"Ok Computer.\\"  Perf. Johnny Greenwood, Ed O'brien, Phil Selway, and   Thom Yorke.  EMI and Capitol Records, 1997.

B002GY9F9K|1.0|To truly review this show it has to be looked at from two angles.  The first is that of someone who has read and enjoyed the books.  Which I have.  In fact I read Wizards First Rule when it first came out ages ago.  I loved it, couldn't put it down (seriously I was up till 3 am finishing it). That disappointement blossomed into shere overwhelming disgust.      In no way shape or form does it follow the books, indeed it only has a few generic world similarities.  The rest of it is so far off that there is no scent of the books left in it.  The lead actor plays an absolutely terrible Richard, at least compared to the strong dynamic individual in the books.  The others aren't nearly so changed however its hard to accept them when the hero is so badly protrayed.      I can think of no one I know who likes the books and also likes the TV show.    That being said for someone who has no knowledge of the books the show is quite engaging.  It would have been a spectacular TV show if it wasn't based on a literary work.  The settings are always quite dramatic and often beautiful, the stories are unique and engaging, and it appeals to lovers of the sword/sorcery genra filling a genra void that has been lurking for quite some time.      If you have the capability of looking past the fact that the show is supposed to follow a book or have never read the books, there is a good chance you will find yourself enjoying the show and anxiously awaiting the next installment.  However if you are a big fan of the books do yourself a favor and just steer clear or its likely your head will explode when you see how badly it has been butchered.

0756405890|2.0|This is one of those books that you dive into eagerly and immediately get swept away, only to be pulled up short 100 pages in when you realise with a jolt that it has actually taken a whole lot of potential and run straight into the ground leaving you feeling cheated. The Name of the Wind is chock full of potential, but most of this is contained in the brief present-day interludes in which the protagonist reminisces about his life. Which is, quite frankly, incredibly yawn inducing and filled with every fantasy cliche and Mary Sue in the good old 'How to write your own completely unoriginal Fantasy Novel' handbook that so many authors rely on these days. The cultural mythology is definitely intriguing and the Chandrian back story had my attention but the writing is mediocre and the development of the characters is pretty amateur.      But the most glaring problem is Kvothe himself. He's INCREDIBLY infuriating. Everybody fawns over him and yet he's utterly, blandly, complacently arrogant. He's the ultimate 1 dimensional Gary Stu. He has no personality, his faults are glossed over, and throughout the book, he DOES NOTHING and there is no personal development. Seriously, it's almost as bad as Twilight, as if Rothfuss forgot that a plot is necessary. And while that may come in the second book, I personally don't want to have to wade through 600 pages of Kvothe attending university and experiencing your average teen angst and personal issues to get to it. Aren't epic fantasies supposed to have excitement, adventure and suspense, and grab your attention with a steadily evolving plot? Not just an arrogant toerag attending a university, squabbling with the school bully and getting all emo lusting after the usual unnattainable-and-ridiculously-gorgeous girl. I'd still read the second book for the contemporary story arc and more about Bast in particular, but I'll be borrowing it, not buying it. I'd venture to say it's Twilight all over again, but that's maybe a little strong.
0375703764|1.0|I read 4-5 books a week.  I love to read.  I've only ever quit reading one book...ever.  And to tell you just how worthless this 700-page door stop is, I struggled to finish this book over a 3-week period.  I rarely comment on Amazon.com, but after (finally) finishing it, I just feel the need to vent.  Because there isn't enough space to describe how worthless this book is, I'm going to concentrate on the few good things I can think of.<br /><br />First off, the only thing I'm grateful for in this experience is that I found someone gullible enough to take it off my hands - for the price of a cup of coffee at a local cafe.  I think I would have paid HER just to get rid of it...either that, or I'd save it for firestarting material.<br /><br />The second-best thing about this book are the pages containing only 1-5 words.  You can really cover some ground and you actually forget for a minute or two that you're wasting so much time with this literary drivel.<br /><br />Third, thank goodness I didn't pay full price for this book.  Not even close.<br /><br />Finally, there was one scene (Truant) that made me chuckle...and the only reason I did is that it was unexpectedly sexually vulgar and completely random, even in a book that defied order & interest.<br /><br />Anyhow, read this book at your own risk.  Faced with a re-read or watching paint dry, I'd be frantically looking for my keys so I could drive to my local hardware store & fill the bed of my truck with some 15 cans of emerald green Olympic interior satin diversion...
